intro: Cyanotis paludosa, commonly known as the marsh bluebell, is a flowering plant native to wetland habitats in Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Commelinaceae and is characterized by its striking blue to violet flowers that bloom in clusters. The plant typically grows in shallow water or moist soil, adapting well to swampy environments. Its leaves are narrow and grass-like, while its stems are often submerged or floating. Cyanotis paludosa plays an important ecological role in wetland ecosystems by providing habitat and food for various aquatic and semi-aquatic organisms.
